title: Replication Crisis Trust Erosion
context: Science is built on replication — if a finding is real, other researchers should be able to reproduce it. But when researchers tried to replicate landmark studies across psychology, medicine, and economics, the results were devastating. 50-70% of studies failed to replicate. The causes are systemic: publish-or-perish incentives, p-hacking, small sample sizes, and journals that only publish positive results. The replication crisis doesn't just affect academia — it undermines public trust in science at a time when that trust is desperately needed.
hypothesis: Published peer-reviewed research is reliable and can be trusted as the basis for decisions.

chain.root: Build decisions on published research without verifying replicability

effects.impact: Billions spent on treatments that don't work as published

effects.label: Public trust in science erodes

dontIf: You're making major decisions based on a single study, no matter how prestigious the journal
You're citing research without checking if it's been replicated
ifYouMust: Look for meta-analyses and systematic reviews rather than individual studies
Check if the study has been replicated — and what the replication found
Be skeptical of small sample sizes, surprising effect sizes, and single-study claims
Prefer pre-registered studies where hypotheses were declared before data collection

alternatives.name: Pre-registration
alternatives.note: Researchers declare hypotheses and methods before collecting data — prevents p-hacking

alternatives.name: Registered reports
alternatives.note: Journals accept papers based on methodology before results are known — eliminates publication bias

alternatives.name: Open science practices
alternatives.note: Open data, open code, and pre-prints enable verification and replication
